unnormalised: Labour unrest at the ABC Garment Factory in Tirupur took a dramatic turn yesterday, 12/06/2024, as 200+ workers staged a sit-in protest demanding better wages and working conditions. The employees, primarily women, allege that the factory management has been flouting several provisions of the Labour Act, including minimum wage regulations and safety standards. According to Union leader, Mr. Kumar, the factory pays its tailors a meager Rs. 8,000 per month, far below the stipulated minimum wage for skilled workers in Tamil Nadu.
normalised: Labour unrest at the A-B-C Garment Factory in Tirupur took a dramatic turn yesterday, twelfth june two thousand and twenty four, as two hundred plus workers staged a sit-in protest demanding better wages and working conditions. The employees, primarily women, allege that the factory management has been flouting several provisions of the Labour Act, including minimum wage regulations and safety standards. According to Union leader, Mister Kumar, the factory pays its tailors a meager rupee eight thousand per month, far below the stipulated minimum wage for skilled workers in Tamil Nadu.

unnormalised: The protestors are also claiming that the factory doesn't adhere to the 8-hour workday rule, often forcing employees to work for 10-12 hours without overtime pay. Adv. Meena Sharma, representing the workers, stated that they have filed a complaint with the Labour Commissioner, seeking immediate intervention and a thorough investigation into the matter. The unrest began after Ms. Lakshmi, a worker, was reportedly injured on 05/06/2024 due to faulty machinery. The Labour Dept. has assigned Inspector, Mr. Rajesh to the case.

unnormalised: As of this morning, 13/06/2024, negotiations between the management and the Union are underway. The outcome of these talks could have significant implications for the garment industry in the region, which employs a large number of workers under similar conditions. Section 144 has been imposed near the factory. Further updates are awaited.
